ranked_diseases.explanation: West syndrome is characterized by the triad of epileptic spasms (infantile spasms), developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia on EEG. Epileptic spasms are the hallmark feature.
Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy that can present with epileptic spasms, though tonic seizures are more characteristic. Often evolves to West syndrome.
TSC1 commonly presents with epileptic spasms in infancy. A significant cause of symptomatic West syndrome, though other features like skin lesions typically present.
TSC2 mutations cause more severe phenotype than TSC1 and frequently present with infantile spasms. Additional features usually develop over time.
X-linked disorder that can present with early-onset epileptic spasms, particularly in females. Associated with severe developmental impairment.
ARX mutations can cause X-linked West syndrome with epileptic spasms. More common in males but can affect females through X-inactivation patterns.
While primarily associated with febrile seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures, some patients can develop epileptic spasms during their disease course.
Can present with various seizure types including epileptic spasms. Important to consider as it's treatable with pyridoxine supplementation.
